intro: Ranunculus maritimus, commonly known as the sea buttercup, is a flowering plant native to coastal regions of the northern hemisphere. It typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils along shorelines, tolerating salt spray and fluctuating moisture levels. The plant features a basal rosette of lobed leaves and produces showy yellow or orange flowers with five petals. Its flowers are usually 2–4 cm in diameter and bloom from spring to early summer. Ranunculus maritimus is an important plant in coastal ecosystems, providing habitat and nectar for various pollinators.
